p: After an apparent 50 year absence from Europe, Ae. aegypti was detected in 2001 in the area of Sochi, Russia and then in 2005 on the Portuguese island of Madeira [ 10]. By 2008, it had re-populated the eastern coast of the Black Sea, with populations reported in Georgia, Russia [ 11, 12] and later (2015) from Turkey [ 13].
